comments.author: hungry gal
comments.content: this can't be real!  I have seen a lot of things.  This, I have not seen.

comments.author: kayce.
comments.content:
i am a fan of the wow factor, but nothing else...  my fave part is a runny yolk, but i HATE runny whites.  soft whites, yes, but runny?  absolutely not.

i would soft poach it like this, then put it over a baby greens salad w/ crispy onion rings, bacon lardons, and a bacon vinaigrette.  YUMMY!  :)

comments.author: Kate
comments.content: I second kayce. Running whites? eh. But it looks awesome.

comments.author: Stef
comments.content: That's so neat!  I've never seen anything like it!

comments.author: let melissa cook
comments.content: Fascinating! I'm curious which Farmer's Market is selling them?

comments.author: veredgy
comments.content:
This are unborn eggs.
It's best to fry them with livers and onion, some salt and pepper and that's all. Try it you'll love it.

comments.author: leah
comments.content: Ha! You almost got me! That's pretty cool.

comments.author: Maggie
comments.content: Hahaha... that is funny.

comments.author: aleta
comments.content: Oh neat, nice find!! Are ya posting a how-to in English, or just leaving us with the link in the comments, eh?

comments.author: sara
comments.content: I had not heard of these, but of course the new york times had, and they have some ideas about how to use them. They are indeed "unborn eggs" (harvested after the chickens have died). see here... http://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/07/dining/07eggs.html?_r=1&th&emc=th

comments.author: The Italian Dish
comments.content: Are these eggs for real? I can't believe it! If you like poached eggs, check out this on my new site: http://tinyurl.com/bateuu They're incredible for poached eggs, I tell you!

comments.author: Melissa
comments.content: That is so neat! I'm not sure what you could make with them, but I would but them just because they were inside out.

comments.author: Sara
comments.content: Ha! Yer funny. What is it really? It's pretty.

comments.author: Leslie
comments.content: I LOVE LOVE eggs, but for some reason, I feel queasy looking at them with the textures reversed.  Isn't that weird?  It must be that the only thing that keeps them from crossing my inner six-year-old's mental line to gross must be the familiarity, but then seeing them out of context totally messes with that.  This is what is so fun about experimental cooking - when it forces you to look at something familiar anew...

comments.author: Angela
comments.content: OMG Michael! How cool is that? I don't know what else to say about it except that now I want one!

comments.content: What a cool photo!!!

comments.content: i love the photo... now there should be easter eggs inside out

comments.content: That is really cool.  But it is very strange too.  Just imagine an inside-out chicken. Or maybe you would rather not.

comments.content: Ok, I have to come clean.

comments.content: That is pure craziness. See what it would look like on Eggs Benedict or even sunny side up.

comments.author: Melinda Tai
comments.content: I have chickens in my backyard--and shall ask if they can make such an egg...How cool is that!

comments.author: inside out egg
comments.content: un born? how would that work? If the eggs we eat are born then we would be eating chicks. if you mean that they havn't come out of the chicken yet, well then we'd see a chicken in the picture

comments.author: lex
comments.content: Actually there is such a thing as unborn eggs.. they are eggs that are taken out of the chicken before they are laid.

comments.content: hey, did you guys know that the word 'gullible' isn't in the dictionary?! look it up!

comments.content: I totally believed it!!!!!!!!!!

Common sense....spin the egg and the yolk breaks.
Boil or cook normal. Its not a special breed of chickens, just a prank.
